author: @mxdwn
title: Coachella Experiences Slowest Ticket Sale In A Decade - mxdwn Music
text: According to [ nme.com](https://www.nme.com/news/music/coachella-sees-slowest-ticket-sales-in-10-years-for-2024-line-up-3577024), this year‚Äôs [Coachella](https://music.mxdwn.com/2024/01/16/news/coachella-announces-2024-lineup-featuring-lana-del-rey-doja-cat-tyler-the-creator-more/) has seen the slowest ticket sales in a decade. As [SFGate](https://www.sfgate.com/sf-culture/article/coachella-festival-sees-slowest-ticket-sales-10-18624027.php) reports, the festival‚Äôs first weekend is still yet to sell out after six days on sale, which is the slowest ticket sales in a decade. Back in 2015, tickets went in less than an hour, while it took less than half a day for the festival to sell out in 2022. Earlier this month, Coachella revealed this year‚Äôs lineup will feature performances by [Lana Del Rey,](https://music.mxdwn.com/2024/01/06/news/lana-del-rey-doja-cat-tyler-the-creator-reportedly-slated-to-headline-coachella-2024/) [Tyler, The Creator](https://music.mxdwn.com/2019/07/13/news/yuna-debuts-personal-new-track-castaway-featuring-tyler-the-creator/) and [Doja Cat](https://music.mxdwn.com/2024/01/15/news/doja-cat-teases-possible-follow-up-to-scarlet-with-new-tracklist/), with a special appearance by a reunited [No Doubt](https://music.mxdwn.com/2022/12/27/news/gwen-stefani-talks-possibility-of-no-doubt-reunion/). Also performing will be [Blur](https://music.mxdwn.com/2023/12/06/news/damon-albarn-says-he-is-wrapping-up-with-blur-for-now-to-focus-on-gorillaz/), Peso Pluma, J Balvin, Ice Spice, Khruangbin, Jhen√© Aiko, Lil Uzi Vert, Justice, [Deftones](https://music.mxdwn.com/2023/11/25/news/chino-moreno-details-madonnas-signing-of-deftones-to-maverick-records-in-1994/), Jungle, Dom Dolla, Bleachers, Peggy Gou, Grimes, a reunited Sublime and others. Coachella 2023 saw the likes of [Bad Bunny](https://music.mxdwn.com/2024/01/09/austin/bad-bunny-at-moody-center-on-april-26-27/), [Blackpink,](https://music.mxdwn.com/2023/06/26/news/the-weeknd-and-blackpinks-jennie-share-new-song-from-the-idol-soundtrack-one-of-the-girls/) and [Frank Ocean](https://music.mxdwn.com/2023/11/09/news/frank-ocean-shares-teaser-for-new-song/) headline the festival‚Äôs two weekends. After [Ocean](https://music.mxdwn.com/2023/04/20/news/ice-skaters-allegedly-slated-for-frank-oceans-coachella-2023-performance-discuss-production-switch-up/)‚Äôs controversial set and his eventual dropping out of weekend two, Skrillex, Fred again.. and Four Tet stepped in to play the closing set.

author: Harry Diamond
title: Arsenal debut delayed after shoulder setback
text:
Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta has confirmed that new signing Mikel Merino will miss ‚Äòa few weeks‚Äô after sustaining a shoulder problem in training.
The Spain international signed for Arsenal from Real Sociedad for a fee that could reach ¬£31.6m earlier this week but has suffered a setback in training.
Arteta has revealed that Merino has injured his shoulder during a training ground ‚Äòcollision‚Äô with Gabriel Magalhaes on Thursday and is expected to miss the next few weeks, due to a ‚Äòsmall fracture‚Äô.
Merino will miss ‚Äòa few weeks‚Äô ‚ÄúVery unfortunate. Yesterday he had a collision and he has a shoulder injury. It looks like he‚Äôs going to be out for a few weeks,‚Äù Arteta said at his pre-match press conference ahead of facing Brighton this weekend.
‚ÄúHe was really excited and everything was looking really good. He landed on the floor and Gabi [Gabriel Magalhaes] landed on top of him and it looks like he has a small fracture probably.‚Äù
Arteta discusses Aaron Ramsdale exit Arteta also thanked Aaron Ramsdale for his service at Arsenal after the goalkeeper signed for Southampton. The England international has joined the Saints for a fee that could reach ¬£25m, having lost his place as first-choice goalkeeper to David Raya.
Arteta said Ramsdale ‚Äòbrought a lot of joy and charisma‚Äô to the dressing room during his time at the Emirates.
‚ÄúThank you so much for what he‚Äôs done for the club, for the team and for myself,‚Äù Arteta said.
‚ÄúHe brought a lot of joy and charisma and was really good when he joined.
‚ÄúHe had a situation that was really good for him. He insisted that he‚Äôs really joyful when he plays and we tried to arrange that.‚Äù

author: Ireland's premier breaking news app
title: Rain helps firefighters slow New Mexico blazes as Biden approves disaster relief
text: More than 1,000 firefighters in the US state of New Mexico took advantage of a break in the weather to gain the upper hand ‚Äì for now ‚Äì on a pair of wildfires that have killed two people, destroyed hundreds of homes and forced thousands to flee. US president Joe Biden issued a disaster declaration for parts of southern New Mexico, freeing up funding and more resources as crews worked to keep the flames from spreading. Their efforts have received a boost from a storm system that brought with it rain, hail and cooler temperatures to the mountain village of Ruidoso and other parts of the state. ‚ÄúThe fire has lost momentum,‚Äù Arthur Gonzales, the fire behaviour analyst for the federal attack team, told residents at a community meeting in Alamogordo on Thursday night. ‚ÄúWe still have a lot of work to do, but it‚Äôs really changed that fire behaviour,‚Äù he added, noting that very little growth in the blaze is expected over the next few days. But firefighters know this is a brief respite given the tinderbox conditions that helped fuel the fires in the first place. Within days, the fires have consumed an area half the size of Washington, DC. ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre really focusing on now at this point is: when might we see this return to active fire spread?‚Äù Mr Gonzales said. ‚ÄúIs there potential for this to start picking up and moving again?‚Äù Federal and local officials said evacuation orders likely would remain in place for days in some places as crews snuff out hot spots around Ruidoso. Law enforcement officers are also patrolling the streets to keep potential looters away. Despite some reports that the fires were caused by human activity, federal incident commander Dave Gessar said the causes are under investigation and remain ‚Äúundetermined‚Äù. The federal disaster declaration will help with recovery efforts, including temporary housing, low-cost loans to cover uninsured property and other emergency work in Lincoln County and on lands belonging to the Mescalero Apache Tribe. Residents fled the larger of the two fires with little notice as it swept into neighbourhoods on Monday. More areas were evacuated on Tuesday as the fire ballooned, consuming homes nestled among the the ponderosa pines that dominate the hillsides. An estimated 1,400 structures have been destroyed or damaged, and Ruidoso mayor Lynn Crawford has estimated about half of these were homes. Whole portions of some communities were lost, he said. ‚ÄúThese are things that are burnt to the foundations and all the trees around it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs devastating.‚Äù Authorities say a 60-year-old man who died was found near the popular Swiss Chalet Inn in Ruidoso. His family said he had arranged for a lift from friends but they were unable to get to him on Monday since the roads were blocked. It appeared he was overcome after he tried to set out on foot. On Wednesday, officers discovered the skeletal remains of an unidentified second person in the driver‚Äôs seat of a burned vehicle. The ongoing heatwave will likely spread to the Mid/Deep South and Southeast early next weekü•µ. Heat index values may exceed 110 degrees in some places. [https://t.co/DGeRdJ7516] ‚Äî National Weather Service (@NWS) [June 20, 2024] A couple of residents have been driving around Ruidoso and neighbouring Alto, providing reports via social media of what they are seeing. There are locations where the ground was turned to ash, the trees were blackened and homes were reduced to their foundations, with only fireplaces remaining. Much of the US south-west has been exceedingly dry and hot in recent months. Those conditions, along with strong winds, whipped the flames out of control, rapidly advancing the South Fork Fire into Ruidoso in a matter of hours. Evacuations extended to hundreds of homes, businesses, a regional medical centre and the Ruidoso Downs horse track. Nationwide, wildfires have scorched more than 3,344 square miles this year ‚Äì a figure higher than the 10-year average, according to the National Interagency Fire Centre. Nearly 20 wildfires burning in California, Arizona, Colorado and Washington state and elsewhere are considered large and uncontained.

author: Syndicated Content
title: Harvard settles lawsuit alleging it ignored sexual harassment
text:
By Nate Raymond
BOSTON (Reuters) ‚Äì Harvard University has settled a lawsuit accusing the Ivy League school of ignoring sexual harassment by a professor who three graduate students said had threatened their academic careers if they reported him.
In a filing on Wednesday in federal court in Boston, the three women ‚Äì Margaret Czerwienski, Lilia Kilburn and Amulya Mandava ‚Äì voluntarily dismissed their 2022 lawsuit following months of mediation with Harvard.
Their lawsuit gained national attention with its claims that John Comaroff, then an anthropology professor, for years kissed and groped students and threatened to sabotage students‚Äô careers if they complained.
Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. The law firm that represented the women, Sanford Heisler Sharp, said it was ‚Äúglad that our clients will now be able to move on with their lives and careers.‚Äù
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre proud of our clients‚Äô courage in coming forward, speaking up about their experiences, and shedding light on important issues,‚Äù the law firm said in a statement.
Harvard and Comaroff‚Äôs lawyer did not respond to requests for comment on Thursday. Comaroff, who retired earlier this year, issued a statement on his website in July calling the allegations false.
When the suit was filed, his lawyers said he categorically denied ever harassing or retaliating against any student.
The #MeToo-era lawsuit followed an internal Harvard investigation that found Comaroff had engaged in verbal conduct that violated professional conduct and sexual harassment policies.
The three women said they were among the students who reported Comaroff to Harvard officials. Despite their warnings, Harvard watched as he retaliated by ensuring the students would have ‚Äútrouble getting jobs,‚Äù the lawsuit said.
They said Harvard‚Äôs inaction allowed Comaroff to repeatedly and forcibly kiss Kilburn and grope her in public, and claimed he graphically described ways she would be supposedly raped or killed in South Africa for being in a same-sex relationship.
The lawsuit alleged Harvard violated Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, which protects students from discrimination based on sex, and various Massachusetts laws. A judge largely rejected Harvard‚Äôs bid to dismiss the case in March 2023.
Comaroff was not a defendant. On his website, he said that as a result of the ‚Äúfact-free allegations‚Äù he had before his retirement become the subject of an ‚Äúugly, ferocious campaign‚Äù by activists on campus who had occupied his classrooms and pressured students not to take courses with him.
(Reporting by Nate Raymond in Boston; Editing by Howard Goller)
